details.title: A practical method for obtaining prior distributions in reliability

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Univ. of Guadalajara, Mexico

p: Humberto Gutiérrez-Pulido received the M.S. in Statistics (1991) from the University of Guanajuato, and the Ph.D. in Statistics (2003) from Centro del Investigación en Matemáticas, Mexico. He is a Professor in the Department of Mathematics at the University of Guadalajara. His current research interest is in industrial applications of Statistics.

authors.name: H. Gutierrez-Pulido

p: Víctor Aguirre-Torresreceived the Ph.D. in Statistics from North Carolina State University in 1982. He is currently a Professor in the Statistics Department at ITAM. He had previously worked in the Math Department, National Polytechnic Institute; Institute for Research in Applied Mathematics, UNAM; Center for Research in Mathematics, Guanajuato; and the Mathematics Department, Oakland University. His current research interests are industrial applcations of Statistics and Econometrics.

J. Andrés Christen received the Ph.D. in mathematics (statistics) from Nottingham University, 1994. His research interests include Bayesian applications in Archaeology, Biostatistics, Bioinformatics, and sequential analysis in clinical trials.

details.abstract: In this paper, we propose a comprehensive methodology to specify prior distributions for commonly used models in reliability. The methodology is based on characteristics easy to communicate by the user in terms of time to failure. This information could be in the form of intervals for the mean and standard deviation, or quantiles for the failure-time distribution. The derivation of the prior distribution is done for two families of proper initial distributions, namely s-normal-gamma, and uniform distribution. We show the implementation of the proposed method to the parameters of the s-normal, lognormal, extreme value, Weibull, and exponential models. Then we show the application of the procedure to two examples appearing in the reliability literature, and . By estimating the prior predictive density, we find that the proposed method renders consistent distributions for the different models that fulfill the required characteristics for the time to failure. This feature is particularly important in the application of the Bayesian approach to different inference problems in reliability, model selection being an important example. The method is general, and hence it may be extended to other models not mentioned in this paper.

references.title: Model selection in reliability: a Bayesian approach

references.title: Optimal Statistical Decisions

context.text: This practice is commonly found in books & papers on Bayesian analysis for models where the parameters have a direct interpretation like binomial, Poisson, N, and E models; see for example [2]–[5], and [6].

If we are able to express the mean \$E(\theta_{j})\$, and variance \$V(\theta_{j})\$ of each parameter in terms of the information that the user provides, we can estimate the hyperparameters of \$\pi({\mmb \theta})\$ by the method of moments when \$\pi({\mmb \theta})\$ is a NG distribution (like in [2] page 170).

Now consider the parameter \$\theta_{1}\$, because its marginal distribution is \$t(m_{i},2\alpha_{i},\alpha_{i}k_{i}/\beta_{i})\$ (see [2], page 171), then \$E(\theta_{1})=m_{i}\$ and \$V(\theta_{1})=(\beta_{i}/k_{i}(\alpha_{i}-1))\$.

references.text: M. H. DeGroot, Optimal Statistical Decisions, 1970, McGraw-Hill.

From this point of view, this method appears to be easier to use than other methods which suppose a previous knowledge about the parameters of the models [7], [8]; and it is less demanding than other proposals which need similar historical data ([7], chapter 6).

links.abstract: Bayes estimation of complicated functions requires simpler estimation techniques due to the mathematical difficulties involved in the classical Bayes approach. Bayes estimation enjoys many approximation techniques and computational methods like Metropolis, and Gibbs sampler. Bayes estimation of the reliability of a mixture inverse Gaussian distribution requires a numerical approach since the calculations are immensely difficult from the exact Bayes point of view. Lack of full conditional prior d...

references.text: O. Akman, L. Huwang, "Bayes computation for reliability estimation", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 46, no. 1, pp. 52-55, 1997.

links.abstract: The paper considers the full Bayes analysis of the Pareto distribution when the observations are doubly censored, and provides sample-based estimates of posterior distributions using Gibbs sampler algorithm. The approach is not only computationally simple but fully explores the low-dimensional posterior surfaces-which otherwise seems difficult. Complexities through censored data always arise in life testing experiments; these complexities are no longer problems with the Gibbs sampler algorithm, ...

references.text: S. K. Upadhyay, V. Shastri, "Bayes results for classical Pareto distribution via Gibbs Sampler. with doubly-censored observations", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 46, no. 1, pp. 56-59, 1997.

links.abstract: Estimation of the reliability function is considered for the inverse Gaussian distribution. When the mean lifetime ¿ is known, the Jeffreys vague prior and the natural conjugate prior for ¿ easily yield Bayes estimators of reliability for squared-error loss. If both ¿ and ¿ are unknown, the Bayes solution for reliability in a compact form is extremely difficult. In this case a modified estimator of reliability can be used which is based on the Bayes estimator obtained for ¿ known. The modified e...

References [17] and [18] propose a method to elicit the prior mean, \$M\$, and prior SD, \$S\$, for a forecast model using quantiles.
Following [18], and [17], we consider two forms to obtain intervals for \$M\$, and \$S\$, depending on whether or not \$f(x\vert{\mmb \theta})\$ is symmetric.
Even though the procedure does not formally require specific quantiles, we agree with [17].

references.text: A. OHagan, "Eliciting expert belief's in substantial practical applications", The Statistician, vol. 47, pp. 21-35, 1998.
